artefact.overview: You may need to tell DVLA if you have angina - download the correct form to let them know
artefact.body:
You may need to tell DVLA if you have angina.

You can be fined up to £1,000 if you don’t tell DVLA about a medical condition that affects your driving. If you’re involved in an accident, you may be prosecuted.

Car or motorcycle licence

You don’t need to tell DVLA.

You may continue to drive if you have angina (even if you need medication) unless it happens while resting, driving, or with emotion. If it does, you must stop driving until your symptoms are under control.

Read ‘Car or motorcycle drivers with heart conditions’ for more information.

Download ‘Car or motorcycle drivers with heart conditions’ (PDF, 129KB)

Bus, coach or lorry licence

You must tell DVLA. Fill in form VOCH1 and send it to DVLA. The address is on the form.

Download ‘VOCH1 - Confidential medical information’ (PDF, 394KB)
